stem: The nurse is providing discharge education for a client starting multidrug therapy for active pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) with Isoniazid, Rifampin, Ethambutol, and Pyrazinamide. Which information should the nurse include?

options.text: Expect your urine, sweat, and tears to turn a harmless orange-red color.
You may stop the medication once your sputum cultures are negative.
Contact the provider if you experience any changes in your vision or color perception.
Report any new yellowing of the eyes or skin (jaundice) immediately.
Avoid drinking alcohol for the duration of the entire treatment course.
Take a Vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) supplement daily as prescribed.

rationale.correct: TB therapy is complex and high-risk. (A) Isoniazid, Rifampin, and Pyrazinamide are all hepatotoxic; jaundice is a sign of liver failure. (B) Rifampin causes orange discoloration of body fluids. (C) Ethambutol can cause optic neuritis (vision/color changes). (E) Alcohol increases the risk of severe drug-induced hepatitis. (F) Vitamin B6 prevents peripheral neuropathy caused by Isoniazid.
rationale.incorrect: (D) TB treatment must continue for the full duration (6-12 months) even if the client feels better or has negative cultures to prevent drug resistance; stopping early is the #1 cause of treatment failure.

answerBreakdown.label: A
answerBreakdown.content: The inclusion of "Expect your urine, sweat, and tears to turn a harmless orange-red color." is necessary to address the underlying physiological instability identified during assessment.

answerBreakdown.label: B
answerBreakdown.content: Selecting "You may stop the medication once your sputum cultures are negative." might delay more critical interventions, as it does not address the immediate life-threatening risk.

answerBreakdown.label: C
answerBreakdown.content: Clinically, "Contact the provider if you experience any changes in your vision or color perception." is the most appropriate finding pointing toward the suspected condition and requiring intervention.

answerBreakdown.label: D
answerBreakdown.content: "Report any new yellowing of the eyes or skin (jaundice) immediately." represents a critical metric that must be monitored to evaluate the effectiveness of the current medical plan.

answerBreakdown.label: E
answerBreakdown.content: The inclusion of "Avoid drinking alcohol for the duration of the entire treatment course." is necessary to address the underlying physiological instability identified during assessment.

answerBreakdown.label: F
answerBreakdown.content: Selecting "Take a Vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) supplement daily as prescribed." is evidence-based as it directly correlates with the primary clinical cues and pathophysiology.

clinicalPearls: Directly Observed Therapy (DOT) is the preferred method to ensure adherence and prevent multi-drug resistant TB (MDR-TB).

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Never choose an option that allows a patient to stop antibiotics or TB meds 'when they feel better' or 'when cultures are clear' before the prescribed date.

mnemonic.title: R-I-P-E
mnemonic.expansion: Rifampin (Red/orange), Isoniazid (INH/Neuropathy/B6), Pyrazinamide (Pseudo-gout/Uric acid), Ethambutol (Eyes/Optic neuritis).

reviewUnits.heading: Anti-Tubercular Pharmacotherapy
reviewUnits.body: Nurses must monitor LFTs regularly. Education focuses on adherence, side effect recognition (Eyes, Nerves, Liver), and the non-infectious transition (after 2-3 weeks of therapy and clinical improvement).
